name: Prostate Anatomy and Function
description: Understanding the prostate gland - what it is, where it is, and what it does
audienceNote: Many men are uncertain about the prostate's location and function - this content addresses common questions openly

1.summary: The prostate is a small gland that helps make the fluid that carries sperm.
1.explanation: The prostate is about the size of a walnut and sits just below your bladder. It wraps around the tube (urethra) that carries urine from your bladder out through your penis. The prostate makes a special fluid that mixes with sperm to create semen. This fluid helps protect and feed the sperm so they can survive and reach an egg. All men have a prostate, and it typically stays the same size until around age 40-50, when it often starts to grow larger.

keyTerms.definition: A small gland in men that helps make semen
The organ that stores urine before you urinate
The tube that carries urine (and semen) out of the body
The fluid that contains sperm when a man ejaculates

analogies: Think of the prostate as a small donut wrapped around a straw - the straw is the urethra, and the donut adds important fluids to the mix.

commonQuestions.question: Where exactly is my prostate?
commonQuestions.answer: It's deep inside your pelvis, below your bladder and in front of your rectum. That's why doctors can feel it during a rectal exam.

2.summary: The prostate is an accessory reproductive gland that produces prostatic fluid, a key component of semen that aids sperm survival and motility.
2.explanation: The prostate is located in the male pelvis, positioned inferior to the bladder, anterior to the rectum, and surrounding the prostatic urethra. In a young adult male, it weighs approximately 20 grams and measures about 4cm wide, 3cm tall, and 2cm deep. The prostate produces approximately 30% of seminal fluid volume. Prostatic fluid is slightly acidic (pH ~6.5) but helps neutralize vaginal acidity to protect sperm. Key components include: prostate-specific antigen (PSA) which liquefies semen after ejaculation, citric acid which provides energy for sperm, and zinc which has antimicrobial properties. The gland is divided into zones: the peripheral zone (where most cancers arise), the central zone (around the ejaculatory ducts), and the transition zone (where benign enlargement occurs).

keyTerms.definition: A protein made by prostate cells that liquefies semen; measured in blood tests to screen for prostate problems
The outer portion of the prostate, closest to the rectum, where 70% of prostate cancers develop
The inner portion of the prostate surrounding the urethra, where benign enlargement (BPH) occurs
Tubes that carry sperm from the vas deferens through the prostate to the urethra

anatomicalLandmarks: Anterior to (in front of) the rectum - allows examination via digital rectal exam
Just above the pelvic floor muscles
2.clinicalRelevance: Understanding prostate anatomy explains why prostate enlargement causes urinary symptoms (compression of urethra) and why the prostate can be examined through the rectum.

3.summary: The prostate is a tubuloalveolar exocrine gland with zonal anatomy that determines disease predilection, androgen-dependent function, and complex secretory products essential for fertility.
3.explanation: The prostate's McNeal zonal anatomy has important clinical implications: the peripheral zone (70% of glandular tissue) is the site of 70% of carcinomas and is easily palpable on digital rectal exam (DRE). The central zone (25% of tissue) surrounds the ejaculatory ducts and is relatively resistant to disease. The transition zone (5% of tissue) is the exclusive site of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and accounts for 25% of cancers. The anterior fibromuscular stroma contains no glandular tissue. Histologically, the prostate contains tubuloalveolar glands with secretory columnar epithelium (expressing PSA, PAP), basal cells (p63+, lost in carcinoma), and rare neuroendocrine cells. The gland is surrounded by a true capsule (important for cancer staging) and a fascial sheath. Prostatic secretions include PSA (kallikrein family serine protease), prostatic acid phosphatase (PAP), zinc (highest concentration of any organ), citric acid, polyamines (spermine, spermidine), and prostaglandins.

keyTerms.definition: Gland structure with both tubular ducts and rounded secretory sacs (alveoli)
Prostatic epithelial cells that don't express androgen receptors; their absence is diagnostic of adenocarcinoma
Fibromuscular layer surrounding the prostate proper; cancer that breaches this is staged as T3a
Elevation on posterior prostatic urethra where ejaculatory ducts and prostatic utricle open

3.clinicalNotes: The posterior peripheral zone location of most cancers explains why DRE can detect abnormalities. BPH occurs exclusively in the transition zone, explaining why medical therapy targeting smooth muscle and 5-alpha reductase is effective.

4.summary: Prostate biology centers on androgen-dependent epithelial-stromal interactions governing development, homeostasis, and disease pathogenesis through testosterone/DHT-AR signaling pathways.
4.explanation: Prostatic development and maintenance depend on androgen signaling through the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. Circulating testosterone enters prostate cells and is converted to dihydrotestosterone (DHT) by 5-alpha reductase type 2 (SRD5A2). DHT binds the androgen receptor (AR) with 10-fold higher affinity than testosterone. The liganded AR translocates to the nucleus, binding androgen response elements (AREs) to regulate gene transcription. Key AR-regulated genes include PSA (KLK3), TMPRSS2, and NKX3.1. Epithelial-stromal interactions are critical: AR signaling in stromal cells produces paracrine factors (FGFs, IGF-1) that support epithelial survival and secretory function. The prostate epithelium contains a hierarchy: basal cells (CD44+, p63+, AR-low) include stem cells; transit-amplifying cells differentiate into luminal cells (AR+, PSA+, differentiated secretory cells) and rare neuroendocrine cells (chromogranin A+, synaptophysin+). This understanding underlies BPH/cancer therapeutics targeting the androgen axis.

keyTerms.definition: Enzyme converting testosterone to the more potent DHT; type 2 predominates in prostate; inhibited by finasteride (type 2) and dutasteride (types 1&2)
Nuclear hormone receptor that mediates testosterone/DHT effects; target of antiandrogen therapies
Communication between stromal and epithelial cells via secreted growth factors
Androgen-regulated homeobox transcription factor essential for prostate development and differentiation; tumor suppressor lost in prostate cancer

4.clinicalNotes: 5-alpha reductase inhibitors (finasteride, dutasteride) reduce DHT levels by 70-90%, shrinking prostate volume and reducing PSA by ~50% (must double measured PSA in treated patients). Understanding AR signaling underpins androgen deprivation therapy for prostate cancer.

5.summary: Contemporary prostate biology integrates molecular pathogenesis, precision medicine approaches, and advanced therapeutics targeting AR splice variants, tumor microenvironment, and genomic alterations.
5.explanation: Advanced prostate pathobiology relevant to clinical practice: 1) Molecular alterations in prostate cancer include TMPRSS2-ERG fusion (50% of cases - androgen-regulated fusion creating ERG overexpression), PTEN loss (40% - PI3K/AKT pathway activation), TP53 mutations (progression marker), RB1 loss (neuroendocrine differentiation), DNA repair gene alterations (BRCA1/2, ATM, PALB2 - 20-25% of mCRPC, PARP inhibitor eligible), and AR amplification/mutations (castration resistance). 2) Castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC) mechanisms: intratumoral androgen synthesis, AR amplification, AR mutations (broadening ligand specificity), AR splice variants (AR-V7 constitutively active, lacks ligand-binding domain - predicts resistance to AR-targeted therapies), and glucocorticoid receptor takeover. 3) Novel targets: PSMA (prostate-specific membrane antigen) for imaging (PSMA PET-CT) and radioligand therapy (Lu-177 PSMA); neuroendocrine markers for treatment-emergent neuroendocrine prostate cancer. 4) Germline genetics: BRCA2 carriers have 8-fold increased prostate cancer risk with more aggressive disease; cascade testing indicated for metastatic cases and strong family history.

keyTerms.definition: Androgen-driven chromosomal rearrangement creating oncogenic ERG overexpression; most common genomic alteration in prostate cancer
Androgen receptor splice variant 7; constitutively active, predicts resistance to enzalutamide/abiraterone
Prostate-specific membrane antigen; glutamate carboxypeptidase overexpressed in prostate cancer cells; target for imaging and therapy
Defective DNA repair (BRCA1/2, ATM mutations) creating PARP inhibitor sensitivity

5.clinicalNotes: Germline genetic testing (BRCA1/2, Lynch syndrome genes) recommended for metastatic and high-risk localized prostate cancer. PSMA PET-CT has revolutionized staging. PARP inhibitors (olaparib, rucaparib) approved for HRD-positive mCRPC. AR-V7 testing in circulating tumor cells can guide treatment selection in mCRPC.

keyPoints: The prostate is a walnut-sized gland that produces fluid essential for fertility
It wraps around the urethra, which explains why prostate problems cause urinary symptoms
Different zones of the prostate are affected by different diseases (transition zone = BPH, peripheral zone = most cancers)
The prostate depends on testosterone/DHT for normal function, which is why hormone therapy works for prostate conditions
